title: CTRL0000917179 - Transcribed Interview of Michael Ahrens, (Sep. 1, 2022)

data.text: JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL,
The interview in the above matter was held via Webex, commencing at 10:05 a.m.
For the SELECT COMMITTEE TO INVESTIGATE
THE JANUARY 6TH ATTACK ON THE U.S. CAPITOL:
This is the transcribed interview of Michael Ahrens
conducted by the House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack on the
U.S. Capitol pursuant to House Resolution 503.
At this time, I'd ask the witness to please state your full name and spell your last
It's Michael Ahrens, and it's A-h-r-e-n-s.
Now, Mr. Ahrens, this will be a staff-led interview,
although members may choose to attend and ask questions.
we are not joined by any members.
At this time, I will note that
and I am an investigative counsel for the
With me from the select committee, -
who are all investigators with the committee.
At this time, I'm going to ask your counsel to please identify himself for the record.
I'm Todd Steggerda, a partner in McGuireWoods, resident in the
Washington, D.C., office of our law firm.
Kelly, an associate at McGuireWoods, and there is no one else here other than the two of
Now, Mr. Ahrens, you are voluntarily here for this
I am joined off screen but in the room by Emily
The ground rules for the interview are as follows.
There is an official reporter transcribing the record of this interview.
reported transcription is the official record of the proceeding.
Please wait until each question is completed before you begin to respond, and we
will do our best to wait until your response is complete before we ask the next question.
The reporter cannot note nonverbal responses, such as shaking or nodding your
head, so it's important that you respond to each question with an audible, verbal
Please give complete answers to the best of your recollection.
And we remind you that it's unlawful to deliberately provide false information to
Congress, and doing so can result in criminal penalties.
Logistically, any time if you want a break, whether for comfort or to speak with
your counsel, please let us know.
Do you have any questions before we get started?
And for the period of November 2020 through January '21, did you have
Mr. Ahrens, can you provide us, please, with your date of birth?
social media accounts at lnstagram and Twitter?
My Twitter handle is @michaelahrens, and my lnstagram is
I graduated from New York University in 2010.
I went to high school in
St. Louis, Missouri, where I'm from.
How long did you work at the RNC?
I started at the RNC in April of 2017.
And what was your role when you started?
I was the rapid response director.
And how long did you do that?
For about 2 years, until the beginning of 2019.
And what role did you take on at the beginning of 2019?
And what were your responsibilities as the communications director?
So they fell into four main buckets:
Let's briefly go through your professional background.
national press; regional and local press;
the research team; and the war room, who handled media monitoring.
And what did that research team do?
So there were staffers broken up between policy-focused research; folks
Now, when you say the research team, does that mean you oversaw the RNC
focused on the 2020 candidates, researching them; and then also a rapid response team
that would keep their eyes and ears on the news and candidate speeches, whatnot.
And as comms director, who did you report to?
Richard Walters, who was the chief of staff.
And how many direct reports did you have in to you?
And they reported directly to you?
They -- I mean, they had -- they had team leads.
It grew along the way, but by the election we were somewhere between 85
people in the -- on the team.
I would say I had maybe five to seven who were senior
members of the communications team that reported directly to me.
And where would you say that, in the reporting structure, you compared to
And who was head of the research team?
His name was Joe Ascioti, A-s-c-i-o-t-i, I believe.
I mean, we both effectively ran the communications
Then, I think, Smedile was her last name.
Cassie was in charge of that first bucket that I had mentioned, the
She was deputy communications director for national press.
We're going to start by talking about the TMAGAC fund raising
And are you familiar with TMAGAC, the fundraising committee?
And in our investigation we've -- from our investigation we
understand generally how the approval process worked, so I'm not going to recap that
TMAGAC, and then that went up to the approval process and included individuals from
both the campaign and the RNC.
But generally our understanding is copy writers at the RNC created copy for
Is that generally what your understanding of what the approval process was for
I wasn't quite sure where the copy originated, but that's my understanding
of the approval portion of it.
Were you on the approval -- let's call it a listserv or chain -- for these emails
So then any emails that were sent and approved for TMAGAC from the
election through January 6th, you would have been at least on the email.
about whether you did anything with that.
But you were on the emails that were sent
I believe that I would have been on all of them, yes.
And what did you understand to be the process that occurred when those
emails were received by the approvals chain?
So typically when content from another department would need to get
sign-off by the RNC, there was a communications sign-off, typically a research sign-off,
and typically a sign-off from legal.
but I just assume that that would be the case for this as well.
And I never had a specific conversation about these,
Then let's move forward to -- well, let's talk about the pre-election
Were you at any time actively involved in approving any copy that was sent out,
whether through the RNC or TMAGAC?
I'm trying to get a sense, Mr. Ahrens, of whether you approved copy that went out
to the general public prior to the election?
Like a press release or something like that?
He's asking about any communications going out.
Well, we can talk about press, but I'm really thinking about specific, like,
emails and text messages, whether they were political or fund raising in nature, but emails
And who did you understand, pre-election, to be involved from the
RNC in approving specifically TMAGAC copy?
To the best of my recollection, that was primarily Cassie Docksey,
Mike Reed, who handled approvals on that content.
And can you give us some -- can you kind of flesh out for us your
Was this something that was really out of your wheelhouse pre-election,
or were you seeing -- overseeing this from a kind of macro level?
I never really recall having much of a role in it.
handled and something that they inherited from their predecessors.
was himself as the research director the cycle before, and Cassie took over that
responsibility from the deputy communications director before her.
And it's possible that, if one of them was at a doctor's appointment or something,
they'd say, "Hey, could you look at something that I'm supposed to look at?" which may
have included an email or like that.
But I don't recall ever being actively involved.
So from the RNC side we have Cassie Docksey.
election that you're aware of, TMAGAC fundraising emails?
Anyone else from the RNC that was approving emails prior to the
If Cassie was on vacation or something, it's possible that, prior to the
election, our press secretary, whose name is Mandi Merritt at the time, would have
I think, in a situation like that, Mike may have just taken over as well.
I also could be conflating it with -- conflating this with approving press releases
There was just a lot of content to approve from across
And what about the Trump campaign side?
Were you aware who was on
prepared a specific kind of copy in some areas and had elected not to do prepared copies
I want to move forward in time to the lead-up towards the
We have received information that TMAGAC, coming into election day, had
Leading up to election day, what role did you have, if any, in deciding or approving
copy that would be sent out post-election day, fundraising copy?
I had no knowledge of it.
So did you have any discussions with anyone about the pre-approval of copy
Did you have any discussions with anyone about preparing copy that would
focus on election fraud issues or election integrity issues that would be sent out
Now, from the RNC legal side, who did you understand to be on the
Justin Riemer, who is the lead counsel, was typically on those emails.
not sure that I remember anyone else specifically.
What did you understand legal to be doing on these fundraising approval
I mean, generally speaking, legal's role in approving content was to check for
As it pertained to specific fund raising emails, I wasn't part of any conversation
about what they were looking for or what their standards were, that sort of thing.
And where did you get your understanding that it was legal's role to check
We had worked on a lot of press releases around election litigation leading
up to -- I mean, really at the start of COVID, maybe March 2020, various lawsuits in
different States that the RNC was involved in.
closely with Justin in developing those.
And so I got to work a little bit more
So from that experience you understood that the value they added was to
check the accuracy of statements going out?
Generally speaking, I viewed that as something that legal was looking for.
And did you know someone by the name of Jenna Kirsch?
I knew Jenna because she used to work on -- she used to be part of the
She was on the research team, I believe, before I was
And she worked with Justin Riemer on the legal team, right?
She did move to the legal team, yes.
And are you aware that she was involved in approving TMAGAC emails as
I don't remember her being involved.
Now, Mr. Ahrens, we've looked through your production, and it
appears that you received, at least through your personal account, a lot of these TMAGAC
And I assume, as com ms director, part of your job was also to be aware of
the messaging that the RNC is sending out through all its various mediums.
I mean, if what you're suggesting is that I would be reading those emails,
those went to a promotions tab, and I wasn't reading them.
Well, no, I'm not suggesting that you're reading each one.
that there are a lot of emails that go out.
generally aware of the messaging that was in those fundraising emails as they went out
I'm trying to get a sense of whether you were
I mean, I really wasn't reading any of them.
knew what I was hearing from the President and from the campaign, I think, in other
forms than the fundraising emails, if that answers your question.
And it would be fair to say that, post-election, the fundraising emails focused
on themes such as election fraud and things of that nature.
Generally, I think that that was something that was maybe touched on, but I
don't recall any specific fraud claims or anything in those emails.
Well, when you say it was maybe touched on, we've looked through a
variety of these emails, and we've spoken to a variety of your colleagues, and those
messages are central to the post-election messaging that's coming out of TMAGAC, not
under -- that's the core of the messaging.
Is that something you were aware of in real time, that that's what the TMAGAC
messaging looked like, or were you not aware?
I was aware that there -- that content like that was focusing on the election
But, like I said, I wasn't aware of and don't recall specific fraud allegations in
Well, Mr. Ahrens, when we look through those emails, we see
from November 4th on messaging that, for example, Democrats are trying to steal the
but is very present in the weeks directly after the election.
And that is a theme that runs through certainly the 2 months post-election,
Did you have any discussions with any senior staff at RNC about the RNC's -- let
Did you have any discussions with senior staff about the content of these
messages going out from the RNC or TMAGAC about the RNC's views on fraud, the RN C's
views on whether the election was stolen, things of that nature?
And what was your focus post -- from election day forward as com ms
Certainly not about the fund raising copy.
I mean, in the immediate aftermath, it was a lot of press engagement.
Most reporters reached out with questions to me.
members of my team, so I was spending a lot of time meeting with them individually and
helping them with new jobs and fixing up resumes, that sort of thing.
I also had to lay off about 60 to 70
We were also gearing up for a big fight in Georgia over the Senate seats there.
That was -- that's mostly what I was doing after the election day.
So besides press engagement, did you do anything that touched upon
how this related to the Presidential election?
Like, is there something that you're referring to, or --
I'm just trying to get a sense of what your role was post-election.
understand that, for example, Michael Reed was involved with the fundraising emails.
He had involvement as it related to election challenges.
Richard Walters, we have a sense of what he was doing.
Trying to get a sense of how you fit into the RNC com ms role here post-election.
What were you doing as -- while this was going on?
So, like I said, I was the sort of first stop for most members of the media who
were -- who had questions about the results, and also took a role in social media.
was historically something that I was a little bit more involved in.
Certainly, if there was a press release, that's something that I likely, but not in
every case, would have had eyes on and a part in.
Mr. Ahrens, I want to go to about a week after the election.
President Biden is declared President-elect on that
And I want to go to about November 11th.
We've reviewed a variety of the approval email chains that you stated that you
Is it fair to say that when people replied all with the approvals, like
Cassie or Michael Reed, you would have been receiving those as well?
And did you ever review those approval chains?
Did you ever provide any feedback on any approval chains?
As it pertained to the fundraising emails?
Did you have discussions offline about the approval chains post-election?
Did you have any discussions with anyone about the substance or the tone
of these fundraising emails post-election at any time?
Did you have any discussions post-election with anyone about whether or
not the RNC would publicly assert that President Trump had won the election?
I want to make sure I understand your question right.
did I have any conversations with the team about -- with the RNC team about the
Yeah, the RNC's position as to publicly stating that President Trump had, in
I mean, I'm sure that that's something that we discussed.
little bit of a blur about with who or when.
The situation was developing from election
So, I mean, I'm certain that we would have discussed messaging around the
When you say you would have discussed messaging, give us a bit of a summary
about what the discussions were like and what conclusions you all arrived at regarding
So, I mean, typically, Mike Reed and I were in communication with Richard
Walters on a pretty regular basis, also Chairwoman McDaniel, and we'd be speaking as
Justin Riemer regularly at different points, but not consistently throughout that period.
And we would just make decisions based on events as they occurred about
how -- what we should say, what the RNC's position -- how that position should be
So we were speaking throughout that period.
Did there come a time where a decision was made that the RNC's position
would diverge from the Trump campaign's position as it pertained to the 2020 election?
I recall there being sort of a, I recall, a divergence occurring around the time
that -- maybe 2 weeks, week or 2 -- I'm not quite sure -- after the election, when folks like
Rudy Giuliani, Sidney Powell, Jenna Ellis got involved in the President's legal efforts.
I don't remember a specific conversation.
It just became clear that that was not
necessarily aligned with our legal efforts and that messaging would -- was going to be
And can you expand on the lack of alignment?
What do you mean by that?
I mean, I'm not a lawyer, so I couldn't give you -- or an election law
expert -- so I couldn't walk through in detail differences between the litigation strategies.
I just knew that they were no longer working as closely as they maybe were prior to that
and that claims that Rudy and Sidney Powell had been making weren't necessarily
something that our lawyers agreed with.
So is it fair to say that the RNC was not in agreement with the statements
that Rudy Giuliani and Sidney Powell were making on behalf of the campaign as it
I would say that that's a fair characterization.
some of them, but not certainly -- not all of them.
And was there also a divergence between, as you saw it, what the RNC was
willing to say about the election and what President Trump was saying about the
And that divergence, was it fair to say, was focused on President Trump was
making claims about massive fraud that was dispositive and that the RNC did not agree
Well, at what period of time are you referring to?
So you noted about a week or -- let's go 2 weeks after the election, the
timing where you suggest there was a meeting or at least an agreement at the RNC to
Let's talk about that time going forward.
I would say it's similar to what I said about our legal team not necessarily
agreeing with everything that Rudy Giuliani and Sidney Powell had said, that I'm sure
there were statements that the President made that the RNC would agree with about the
election results and certain statements that he made that we wouldn't necessarily have
And what kind of statements would you, RNC, not have promoted?
I mean, I would need to see an example of a statement.
would -- yeah, I would just need to know when it was made and a little bit of context
You know, to give you an example, the President gave, as I'm sure you're well
aware, gave a speech on January 6th.
specific claims that were made in it to cite to you now, but I do recall coming away from
that thinking, okay, I'm not sure that some of these statements are things that the RNC
So let's talk a little bit more specifics, though.
believe in November and December the President was making claims that thousands of
dead people had voted in a way that was dispositive, that kind of fraud.
Did you have discussions about those statements regarding dead people voting?
I don't remember any discussion about the President's statements about
Did you have discussions within the RNC that the RNC would not -- well,
Mr. Ahrens, let me rephrase that, let me give you some background.
We've looked at a variety of these approval email chains, and what we see in a
variety of examples -- which I'm happy to show you, but for the sake of time I'm not going
to pull them up just yet, but anything I'm referencing, to be frank, your lawyer has seen
these before, so he can help validate what I'm saying.
But we see emails coming out from -- revisions coming from Justin Riemer and
Jenna Kirsch specifically that happened about November 11th through November 20th
where there are edits made that appear consistent with what you're saying, which is a
divergence between what President Trump is claiming, or the campaign, and the RNC.
So, for example, in one email Mr. Riemer removes a line that Joe Biden should not
wrongfully claim the office of the President.
line that says that President Trump won the election by a lot and, instead, says a whole
different phrasing, that he got 71 million votes, as opposed to saying he won the election.
Jenna Kirsch makes edits of a similar ilk, meaning that they removed one line that
says Joe Biden did not win the election.
Are those kind of edits consistent with the divergence between the RNC and the
In another email, Mr. Riemer removes the
You know, I definitely am -- I'm here to be helpful, but I never saw that email
or those revisions or -- and so it's a little difficult for me to give you a complete answer on
that, just because I don't really know what you're referencing.
Would it be helpful for me to pull them up?
that I know you didn't -- you said you weren't replying to them, but you were receiving
So I'm happy to pull them up if that would help provide some context.
Yes, because, I mean, I can almost guarantee you I never opened any of
these, so this would be me seeing them for the first time.
Maybe another way that would be helpful to the committee is,
did you have any awareness in this period from November 11th to 20th that you can
remember where legal appears to have been softening the TMAGAC fundraising emails?
that would also be the case, but I don't ever recall reading any of their edits to fundraising
Only to the degree that legal typically softens language in any sort
They try to -- I usually view them as trying to be a little more
But as it pertains to the fund raising emails, I would assume that
Hey,.would you -- I know if-- I don't know if you're going to
pull these up or not, but would you mind if we took a quick just 5-minute break?
I wanted to make sure we're breaking.
So, Mr. Ahrens, we were talking about you had previously mentioned a
divergence between the RNC and the Trump campaign as it related to statements or
actions being taken by Rudy Giuliani and Sidney Powell that RNC legal was not fully
Now, I want to talk specifically about President Trump and whether or not
you had discussions about the RNC diverging because of statements and actions he was
taking as it pertained to claims regarding the election and claims regarding fraud that
went on that he made post-election.
Did you have discussions about that kind of divergence, or any awareness about
I mean, there were -- the President -- the former
President would say something, and if it was controversial, oftentimes those folks that I
mentioned before, like the chairwoman, Mike Reed, Richard Walters, and I would usually
have a brief follow-up discussion about it.
I'm sure that that carried through after the election.
Not always, but it kind of depended on the
And that happened as a regular course of the job before the election, and
Now, when you say "things that were controversial," is it fair to say that
President Trump sometimes made claims post-election about things that were false that
you and the chairwoman and Mr. Walters and Mr. Reed would then have to discuss about
Usually what would happen is a reporter would ask -- would reach out and
ask for the RNC's view on a statement that the President made, particularly if it pertained
to us or something that we were involved in.
and we would decide how we were going to handle it.
No specific event like that pops out in my mind, but I'm sure that there were cases
That would spur a discussion internally
When you say "cases like that," cases about the President saying things that
And did you have discussions with the chairwoman about how the RNC
would deal with false statements from President Trump about the election?
Well, like I said, it was usually more like a case-by-case basis.
there was a moment where we said, "Okay, this is the standard that we are going to
Typically she would have conversations with the legal team, or I would have
conversations with the legal team, and some group of us would sort out how we were
going to handle a given news event or a statement, that sort of thing.
So is it fair to say that, if the President said something that was, for lack of a
better term, more extreme, the RNC might make a statement that diverged?
If we had disagreed, we may diverge, and if we
Are you basically saying you took the President's statements on a
case-by-case basis on whether or not the RNC would publicly diverge from them as it
But sometimes -- I mean, the President spoke a lot.
President would say something and we would neither repeat it or diverge.
usually depend on -- a lot of times it would depend on if we were asked about it, at least
Now, did you have any discussions from the com ms perspective as to the
specific claims that the election was stolen through dispositive fraud?
And I'm not talking about what we would call election integrity that's often
referenced or things of that nature, but, for example, things that are more of the ilk of
dead people were voting, or so-called illegal immigrants voted, things that would be
traditional election fraud that the President was making claims about.
Did the RNC have discussions post-election as to whether it would diverge from
I mean, not -- certainly not to the level of -- I mean, we
had discussions about generally where there was a news report about a dead person
voting or a noncitizen voting as some localities were trying to do.
a discussion as it pertained to that amount of fraud that you've cited, from instances that
you've cited, was going to impact the outcome of the election and lead to Trump winning.
Can you just rephrase that last part for me?
sure I understand what you're saying.
I don't recall a specific conversation about there being so much fraud from
dead people voting or noncitizens voting that it would change the outcome of the
election, because I took your question to mean -- I took the context of your question to
be that the President had said that.
Did you have any discussions that the RNC as an institution or senior
So I don't think we -- I don't ever recall a conversation about that.
leadership would not make claims that President Trump had legitimately won the
like I said before, I'm sure we generally had conversations about messaging around the
election results, and I think that those evolved as the results evolved.
So let's go to just again November 20th.
lawyer has seen them -- there seems to be a softening of language from the RNC legal
team about removing claims that President Trump had won the election.
As I told you -- which, again, I'm happy to show you the emails, your
Would it be fair to say that it was your understanding that the RNC senior
leadership was in agreement with that, that they would also not claim that
President Trump had won the election?
I think that that's fair, although I would just say -- like, I haven't seen those
emails, and so I don't know exactly what the softening is that you're referring to.
Well, even without those emails, just from your perspective, from your
vantage point as com ms director, was it the RNC's position that President Trump had not
won the election by the time you get to the end of November?
Yeah, I -- yes, I don't recall us stating that unequivocally he had won the
election or that that was part of the messaging that was coming out of the RNC.
Certainly not messaging that I produced.
And was the reason for that messaging because at that point the RNC had
not seen -- there was not evidence of fraud to support that President Trump had won
the -- had, in fact, won the election?
Well, I mean, we weren't saying that because there was -- yeah, there was
not evidence that we had seen that he won the election, that Biden had not won the
And, Mr. Ahrens, we've reviewed messages that you exchanged with Cassie.
And if I could ask -- we could pull them up.
exhibit 25 and page 4 of that document.
And we can pull it up in one second.
If we could have that pulled up, that would be great.
Maybe we don't have that ready.
Let me make sure it's page 4.
But before we do, it's a November 23rd email, your lawyer has seen this, in
This would be what's been marked as
So, Mr. Ahrens, can you see this document up?
So if we look at the top of page 5 here, these are, I believe, Gchat or
messages you're exchanging with Ms. Docksey.
And you see at the top here, you
Can we start at the bottom of page 4, please?
In the last two messages here you say -- you tell Cassie, "Send some standard
language about importance of vote/integrity to Sara and Richard, please, and see if they
want us to engage or ignore."
And then, starting on the top of page 5, you say, "Should have something we can
And then she says, "And there we have it.
respond and defend Trump,' end quote."
I was reading from my own document
You can look at the top --
Yeah, if you can just give him 30 seconds to read that feed.
And then you say, "So better to check."
But can keep it tucked away in
And then you respond, "Yeah, I am done getting yelled at for, quote, 'RNC did not
I was reading off my own
I thought we were scrolling -- the team was scrolling.
So, if you look at the top there of page 5, Mr. Ahrens, do you see what I was
On the right column would be the message preview text.
What was -- and what was my -- what started the conversation?
Go back to -- if you could go back to page 4,llllthat
would be helpful, at the bottom.
could let him just read that for a second,-.
Best recollection of what that was about?
I think, based on the language I'm using,
that would have been a media inquiry that we received and that maybe there had been
some concern in the past about us not getting a quote in a story.
So with reference to the line where you say, "I am done getting
yelled at for, quote, 'RNC did not respond and defend Trump,"' what were you
I mean, I can tell you that, generally
speaking, the former President and his team were very sensitive to whether folks were
defend a statement that he had made or an action that they had taken.
And so you often had a -- there was often a pressure to go out and
So here -- and is it fair to say, when you say, "I'm done getting yelled
at," that this was a pattern?
Well, I assumed what would happen is that someone from the President's
team or the White House -- the President himself, the White House, whatnot, would
express to the senior leadership at the RNC, "You guys should be out there doing more,
et cetera, et cetera," and then that would get relayed to me.
In this case, I don't know what that was referring to.
Were there any discussions you had about how much the RNC would, in fact,
defend President Trump or the Trump campaign or decisions that the RNC would not
defend the campaign on certain issues?
You know, I'm sure, like I had said before, they would come up in situations
where the President said something that maybe our team wasn't comfortable with and
we would talk through how to handle that.
And what's an example of that?
You know, I don't -- it did happen frequently.
through the statement that was said, the conversation that we had afterwards, and then
I'm not trying to be cagey or
I just -- I don't know of a specific example that I could cite where I could walk
Just it's been a couple of years.
Well, you said it seemed like you're suggesting or you said it happened
So can you think of an example post-election?
I would need -- sitting here right now, I can't think of a specific example.
Is it fair to say that there were -- it happened numerous times that related to
the President's claims about the election?
Yeah, it happened during this period.
I don't know how -- it wasn't a daily
thing, but oftentimes he would go and give a speech or say something provocative, and
we would get a press inquiry about it.
impetus for our internal discussion on it.
And oftentimes that would guide -- be the
And when you say "something provocative," it's fair to say a lot of times
those things were also just false statements?
And so, in these examples, the President would say something false about
the election, and then the RNC would have a discussion as to how to respond to that false
Well, and like I said, usually -- if he said something that was false and it was
particularly outlandish, we would not have necessarily had a conversation about it.
if a reporter had reached out and said what's the RNC's position on this statement, that
would usually be what would cause us to have a conversation.
with whatever the President said, true or not true, we would, like, meet to talk about it.
And, when you say "we," who are you referencing?
Typically it was some collection of Mike Reed, me, Justin Riemer, Richard
usually maybe not all of us, maybe just a one-on-one conversation, but we were
having -- we were in regular communication.
To a lesser extent, but sometimes Chairwoman McDaniel.
So is it fair to say on issues that garnered a lot of media
attention -- well, let me rephrase that.
garnered a lot of public attention, those are likely the kind of things that you all would

If anything comes up, Mr. Ahrens, you remember something, you want to clarify
something, we didn't ask you something you thought we should know, don't hesitate to
reach out to your lawyer who can update us on anything that might come to mind after
Well, you both -- well, all three of you, I should say, have a
great day and thank to you our court reporters as well.
[Whereupon, at 12:10 p.m., the interview was concluded.]
I have read the foregoing _ _ pages, which contain the correct transcript of the
answers made by me to the questions therein recorded.
